intro: Pseudocamelina campylocarpa, commonly known as the woolly false camelina, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as mustard and cabbage. The plant is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and small, yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. Its seeds are enclosed in siliques, a type of dry fruit typical of the Brassicaceae family. Pseudocamelina campylocarpa is adapted to arid environments and is often found in disturbed soils and rocky areas.
